docs.lead_paragraph: As F.B.I. agents and forensic accountants sift through the books of National Century Financial Enterprises, one question has presented itself over and over: How did a swashbuckling entrepreneur named Lance K. Poulsen manage to use $3.35 billion in highly rated bonds to finance a series of money-losing health care companies most banks would not touch? Credit Suisse First Boston, the underwriter of the bonds, has one answer. It joined a chorus of other injured parties yesterday when it issued a press release accusing the company of ''massive fraud.'' The underwriter said it would take a $214 million write-down on $258 million worth of National Century bonds it owns.

headline.main: Behind a Lender's Crash, Bravado and Risk

docs.abstract: National Century Financial Enterprises, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and its former chairman, Lance K Poulsen, have history of court cases alleging fraud; company's business was to provide cash to hospital and home-health-care companies in exchange for rights to money due them from slow-paying insurance companies and to package those receivables into collateral for highly rated bonds that were then sold to investors, who received interest derived from insurance payments; Credit Suisse First Boston, bonds' underwriter, alleges massive fraud and will take $214 million write-down on $258 million of National Century bonds its owns; at least five National Century client companies are forced to file their own Chapter 11 petitions, and others are scrambling to find alternative financing; holders of $3.35 billion in National Century bonds, now defunct, are fighting for restitution in court; photos (M)
docs.snippet: As F.B.I. agents and forensic accountants sift through the books of National Century Financial Enterprises, one question has presented itself over and over: How did a swashbuckling entrepreneur named Lance K. Poulsen manage to use $3.35 billion in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Plunging tax collections and soaring medical costs have created the worst fiscal problems for states since World War II, the National Governors Association said today. ''Nearly every state is in fiscal crisis,'' the governors said in a new report surveying the states.

headline.main: STATES ARE FACING BIG FISCAL CRISES, GOVERNORS REPORT

docs.abstract: National Governors Assn fiscal survey of states says plunging tax collections and soaring medical costs have created worst fiscal problems for states since World War II; says problems will force governors, many newly elected, to propose politically sensitive tax increases or drastic cuts in services; says Medicaid and other health benefits account for 30 percent of state spending and grew in 2001 by 13 percent, largest increase in decade; other findings detailed; assn executive director Raymond C Scheppach predicts huge cuts in Medicaid in coming year beyond cutbacks already enacted; says at time when revenues are declining, such growth is unaffordable and unsustainable; governors and state budget officials say fiscal condition of states is more dire than condition of national economy; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: Plunging tax collections and soaring medical costs have created the worst fiscal problems for states since World War II, the National Governors Association said today.    ''Nearly every state is in fiscal crisis,'' the governors said in a new report...

docs.lead_paragraph: Starting today, the public will have a scorecard that names hospitals in New York State where relatively high numbers of patients die during treatment for life-threatening conditions. The listing, compiled by an organization that promotes health care quality, provides information on more than 200 hospitals. The sponsors said the report, which will be posted on the Web today and updated annually, should ultimately lead to better care for patients as the hospitals strive to improve their ratings.

headline.main: Report Rates Hospitals in State on Care in Life-Threatening Illnesses

docs.abstract: Alliance for Quality Health Care publishes study showing New York State hospitals where relatively high numbers of patients die during treatment for life-threatening conditions; table shows example of how three New York City hospitals fared in treatment of stroke patients; report is available free online; it is latest in growing national effort to help consumers find most experienced and skilled hospitals and doctors (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.N. Weapons Inspectors Set to Begin in Iraq United Nations inspectors are scheduled to arrive today in Baghdad. The team plans to make its first inspection on Wednesday, when it will begin scouring for telltale equipment, chemicals and documents that could provide clues that Iraq has rekindled covert biological, chemical or nuclear programs. A1 The United States is forging an alliance of convenience with a Shiite cleric who has been living in Iran as the effort goes forward to try to unseat Saddam Hussein. Much of Baghdad is populated by Shiites and Shiites dominate southern Iraq, the principal invasion route that American forces would take in Iraq. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Diane MacPherson, of Lowell, Mass., lost her job at a relocation management company last November, and with it the health insurance for herself, her husband and their 4-year-old daughter. Her husband works in construction and does not have access to health care coverage at work. Continuing her family health insurance under the federal Cobra program would have cost $931 a month, so the couple decided to insure only their daughter, at a cost of $270 a month. Two months ago, when Ms. MacPherson's unemployment compensation payments ran out, they dropped their health insurance altogether. Although her husband earns about $75,000 a year, construction work is seasonal and they could not be assured of enough income every month to pay for health insurance.

headline.main: Problem of Lost Health Benefits Is Reaching Into the Middle Class

docs.abstract: Health care crisis, once thought to be problem chiefly of poor and unemployed, is spreading up income ladder and deep into ranks of those with full-time jobs; Census Bureau statistics show 1.4 million Americans lost health insurance in 2001, increase largely attributable to economic downturn and resulting rise in unemployment; largest group of newly uninsured, approximately 800,000, had incomes in excess of $75,000; either lost jobs or were priced out of health care market by rapidly rising insurance premiums; many of new job losses are in high-wage industries, like technology and telecommunications; study by Center for Studying Health System Change finds 30 million Americans in working families, or 16 percent of those in families headed by worker, lack health coverage; additional 16 million, mostly low-income workers, are offered health insurance through jobs but decline because they get health care from government programs, or because premiums are too expensive; charts; graphs; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST summer, Korey Stringer, the Minnesota Vikings' 335-pound offensive tackle, died of heatstroke during training camp. Team officials said they discovered an empty bottle of Ripped Fuel, a dietary supplement manufactured by the Hauppauge-based Twinlab Corporation, in his locker. His death brought renewed impetus to a widespread campaign, nearly a decade in the making, to ban supplements like Ripped Fuel that contain the herb known as ephedra or ma huang. Its active ingredient, ephedrine, is a central nervous system stimulant similar to amphetamine.

headline.main: Debate on Ephedra, Herbal Stimulant, Hits Home

docs.abstract: Article on impact on Twinlab and NBTY, Long Island companies that produce dietary supplements, as debate over safety of herbal stimulant ephedra heightens; Twinlab chief executive Ross Blechman says company will discontinue sale of products containing ephedra on March 31, 2003; NTBY spokesman Carl Hymans says company has no plans to remove product; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are places in rural Connecticut so rich in history that unearthing the past, as Stanley Moroch discovered, is literally only a matter of digging. Last April, at an 18th-century burying ground in Colchester, Mr. Moroch spotted what appeared to be a tombstone in some freshly plowed earth near a weed-covered mound.
docs.abstract: Article on long-lost 18th-century burial crypt of Bulkeley family in Colchester, Conn; state archaeologist Dr Nicholas Bellantoni and student volunteers have been excavating site, believed to be makeshift winter morgue, since May 2001; at least 28 family members will be reburied in crypt next spring; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tenet Healthcare, already under scrutiny for receiving unusually high Medicare payments in recent years, apparently charged patients high prices for drugs as well, according to a new analysis by the California Nurses Association to be released tomorrow. In recent years, Tenet-owned hospitals have raised their drug prices to roughly eight times actual costs, the association said. Tenet, one of the nation's largest commercial hospital chains, has come under intense scrutiny for the unusual amount of special Medicare payments it has received in recent years. By raising prices sharply at some of its hospitals, particularly in California, Tenet received hundreds of millions of dollars in special payments. Federal regulators are now looking into those payments to make sure they were proper. Tenet says it has broken no rules.

headline.main: Nurses' Association Says in Study that Big Hospital Chain Overcharges Patients for Drugs

docs.abstract: California Nurses Assn finds that Tenet Healthcare, already under scrutiny for receiving unusually high Medicare payments in recent years, apparently charges patients high prices for drugs as well; finds that in recent years, Tenet-owned hospitals have raised their drug prices to roughly eight times actual costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MURIEL SIEBERT'S new book, ''Changing the Rules: Adventures of a Wall Street Maverick'' (Free Press, $25), can be read in multiple ways. On one level, it is the story of how a young woman from Cleveland drove to New York in 1954 in a Studebaker and, in 1967, at the age of 35, became the first woman to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. Throughout her life, she took risks that other women wouldn't and overcame barriers that other women couldn't. But it's also possible to read the book just for the adventure and the humor. Ms. Siebert and her co-author, Aimee Lee Ball, have come up with some wickedly funny lines. When Ms. Siebert joined the stock exchange, all of the other 1,365 members were men, and there was a great deal of speculation about where Ms. Siebert would go to the bathroom because there were no women's restrooms on the exchange floor. ''Not since I was a baby had so many people been so interested in my bathroom habits,'' she writes. When she became New York State's superintendent of banking in 1977, she was amused by the initials of her title and concluded that yes, ''a woman can be a S.O.B.''

headline.main: A Wall Street Woman Who Cleared a Path

docs.abstract: William J Holstein Book Value column reviews Changing the Rules: Adventures of a Wall Street Maverick by Muriel Siebert, first woman to buy seat on New York Stock Exchange; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is instructive and humbling, after 20 years in this business, to be reminded that what I think I have written is not what others think they have read. I received such a reminder with my last column. What I had meant to write, and what I thought I had written, was one man's opinion, some of which I agreed with and some of which I questioned. The man, Stephen Viscusi, owns a head-hunting firm and is host of a radio show on which he gives career advice. He is also gay, and the column I wrote was about his decision not to share that fact with co-workers over the years. When callers ask whether they should come out to employers, or, more particularly, potential employers, he tells them no.

headline.main: Some Outspoken Opinions on Coming Out
